Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2011 01:37PM dreamwriter wrote: Number 1 Change your cutlery to plastic (the metal adds to the metallic taste). Number 2 Have a glass of water with a drop of lemon in it before your meal.   It helps cleanse the palate. Number 3 It is better to stick to bland foods.... you dont expect them to taste sensational.  I personally had oatmeal whenever food did not appeal to me.  Number 4 Eat lots of fruit - especially those melon, watermelon, honeydew salads.  Again they cleanse the palate.  Be adventurous - eat the salad first - then eat your main meal. Number 5 If you find you are losing weight talk to the hospital dietician.  She would have more suggestions for you.  Just dont lose enough that they recommend meal replacement drinks - they are NASTY.

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2009 06:48PM dreamwriter wrote: Not bitch 10  Bitch 0 So many people responded but forgot to keep the count going..... lol. I dont care if someone is in the same boat - I wish to hell they werent.  I weep for those suffering.  Fatigue seems to be the one that gets us.  Being without energy to read or sew.... And then the sisters who join the angel wall.  So sad.  But one day my name will be there.  Better be or I will haunt everyone with computer skills til it is. HAHAH.  Gallow humour. When the non Metsters are here we cannot let loose our anger, anguish etc.  You dont want to scare someone silly.  I am always careful when I talk in chat to newbies not to be too flip about being stage 4.  I know this disease will kill me.  And I will die a mindless blithering idiot due to liver mets.  It wont be nice and it will be painless.  And thats my future.  But it is the future, so I leave it there.  I try not to think of it more than once or fifty times a day. Im doing stuff.  Traveling for the first time. Sewing a storm of new clothes.  Its almost a new art form for me.  I got tired of puzzles and reading.  I try to read a bit each day but not hours at a time like I did at first. Being stage 4 means that each time a friend passes, you remember that your number can be pulled out of the water any time.  Those boats have numbers you know. I hope I scream something rude when I go over the falls.

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2011 04:16PM dreamwriter wrote: I agree that once you have a plan in place you start to look forward.  For me, I dropped out of a world of work and volunteering to a medical rabbit hole.  Until you can grip what is going on, its like you are following and just staying with the flow.  As you gain knowledge, a piece of "scared" will drop away, a bit at a time.  Until you feel more like your normal self, ask for prescription help.  Anti anxiety and anti depressants are common.... this is a major stressor .... dont be afraid to ask for that help.  You can back off it whenever you want.  We are here to help you along this corridor of your life... ask us, ask the nurses, ask the doctors - leave no question unanswered.  As for emotional support, the hospital, and the oncology department have social workers who can put you in touch with someone to talk to.  And then there is US - givers of cyber hugs - (((((((Windy))))))

WTF... dont they have a pharmacy?  Why do I have to give a hospital medication..... oooops that was a different rant.  A rant on the road to the real rant..... Why cant they eliminate mets, one atta time?  It may be the only way to start now... but taking out the cancer would slow the whole process - YES?  Only MHO.  Right now I feel that they care more about if I poop then if I am in pain.  Is pooping necessary to curing cancer?

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2010 03:55PM - edited Jan 30, 2010 03:57PM by dreamwriter My friend was nursing her second child many years ago and my youngest was very interested in the process.  She watched and listened and asked questions and it was all so very natural and cute.  The next day we were grocery shopping and my blond cutie stopped EVERY woman she saw and announced, "You have nipples".  Red as a beet and laughing so hard my air was diminished, I rushed out of the store to explain that you didnt discuss body parts in public. So we went back inside and she did it : "You have nipples but you dont have to discuss it because this is pubic."  Red as a beet, I continued shopping with my eldest's hand over my youngest's mouth.  When I got to the ice cream aisle I bought creamsicles, ripped open the package and gave them both one.  Something I usually dont do (open a package before paying for it) but it kept one mouth shut and thanked the other for her help. edited to correct a mispelling

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2009 02:18PM dreamwriter wrote: I find that my arm is an indicator of health.  If it gets red and swells more than usual, there is something going on... from pneumonia to a UTI.  There is something that needs attention.  I wear a sleeve when travelling and for days were I am more active.  I agree with all that Binney said so do not need to repeat.  The problem seems to be that once that arm swells, it never goes back to what it was, and you have a new "normal".  I have yet to hear someone say that their lymphedema is under control and they have no swelling. However I agree with Binney, once your sunburn is taken care of you will be fine.  And do consult the Lymphadema Therapist .... she can tell you how to protect those arms...
Posts.Title: Forgot Sunscreen - Lymphedema? chicago-37 Binney4

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2010 11:50AM dreamwriter wrote: It will get better.  Things have changed in the last ten years of nursing.  You would be surprised what a Palliative nurse can do.  I have been there.  The nursing staff is plentiful and your needs are never left untended.  While I was there, my room-mate passed and the lesson I learned was that it was a short peaceful passing.  Nothing to be scared of.  That off my plate, I began to focus on what I wanted to do while I was still LIVING. I did not know at the time that they were preparing me as they thought I would pass within months.  That was 4 yrs ago... I celebrate 5 yrs with this disease in Dec.  And I plan to be here for another bunch of Christmases.  I beat back all the statistics.  And so will you.  More and more of us are reaching that 5 year mark. So focus.... what do you want to do in the next 5 years.  Are there relationships to mend?  Are there places you want to go, faces you want to meet?  I went to two get-togethers and met sooo many of these wonderful ladies.  And it is so wonderful to be accepted into the fold.  Think about going if you get a chance. I like you have liver, lung, spinal mets.  It is very slowly progressing.  But we keep slowing that crawl to slo motion.  Sooner or later maybe we can turn it around and gain back some of the ground.

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2009 11:06PM dreamwriter wrote: I had a flu like sickness just after I had chemo and I ended up throwing up and needing diapering at the same time.  They put me on antibiotics but did not tell me that it changed urine and anything else bright highliter green/yellow.  I thought it meant I was dying.  It meant that I was to have as little human contact as possible.... 7 days without a friend visiting me.  I was so sad.  When they finally opened my door.... I just stood and stared out.  It was a long 7 days.  At the end of it, they told me it was a Norwalk similar type flu.... I just wanted to get out of there cause I had nothing to do and no one to talk to.  No one gave me a sponge bath.... so when the door opened I pleaded for a shower and they felt sorry for me and three nurses ran me to the shower, scrubbed me down, wrapped me in towels and then popped me into a clean robe and clean linens..... fell asleep with a smile on my face! Oh I forgot, I know find out about uti's if there is blood when I wipe or I fall off the toilet.  Not a pretty sight but it seems that I cannot show a fever so it goes septic quickly.  Boy just when I wanted a rest from all these complications.....!

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2010 05:44PM dreamwriter wrote: I have been getting pamidronate every 4 wks since January 2006.  What kind of side effects do you get?  I have had the worst of my pain taken care of by radiation.  We are looking at radiating my left shoulder to give me more mobility.  Depends on if the shoulder if frozen or if there is a tumour there.  Waiting to hear from my friendly radiation oncologist.  Last time he took care of a lower back tumor and the hip - the laser moving to go around the head of the femur.  Since the final two radiations on Valentines Day my walking has improved to the point that I can walk about a half a block.  I no longer walk hunched over like a 90 year old.  It doesnt sound like much - I ran marathons in my teens and early womanhood.  Twenty six miles, 10 miles.... it was a thrill.  Now I sometimes have to take the scooter to get around the block.  I dont know if this is a confession or rant... lol.  I know I will never RUN again.  But it would be lovely to take a really nice long walk with my hubby.

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2010 12:51PM - edited Jan 5, 2010 12:52PM by dreamwriter I think that venting is essential.  And being funny is a necessity.  Can I tell you a funny story.... hope you laugh... I was finished my first round of chemo and thought that I was done with chemo forever.  I wore a pink baseball cap over my stringy hair/bald head (I couldnt even lose all my hair right).  I had a doctors appt and next door was a barber.  I took it into my head to have the uneven hair shaved to start growing in looking even and neat.  However I did not have any cash on me.  I stuck my head in to ask if they took debit.  Im talking to my husband on the cell to see that the money was in the right account.  The barber looks at me and asks who the one getting the haircut and what did they want.  I said it was me and I wanted a short shave.  He laughed so I took off my hat.  He finished with the guy he was doing then sat me in the chair. "No charge," he said.  "My wife, she had breast cancer and I had to shave her head.  And tonight when I tell her what nice thing I do for you - maybe I get lucky tonight." It was a wonder I didnt fall out of the chair laughing so hard.  Everyone has their motivations and he was up front and personal with his. edited for spelling mistake

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2010 02:39PM dreamwriter wrote: I am not triple negative = however I do have mets to bone, liver and lungs.  I just celebrated my 4th cancerversary.  It have been 4 yrs since I was told that I was stage 4 - no cure.  When I saw that, I was stunned.  But I gathered my resources and although I no longer work, I started sewing and quilting.  I made afghans.  I made new friends.  You cannot act irresponsibly and blow a lot of money and then live 10 yrs in debt.  Yes make family memories but be yourselves = not lottery winners where the end prize is your life insurnace covering nothing but debts.  And do not blow your money on some quack with soup.  If the soup cured cancer, do you not think that it would be used for the millions of people WITH cancer.  Instead some nut is trying to sell you hope in the form of soup.  Your diet is just fine.... except I would speak to a dietician about weight loss (not good)  and if you should avoid certain foods (but I think that that is just for us estrogen positive gals). If you need someone to talk to just ask.... If you want it to be me..... just click on Private Messages at the top (see it says 1 New) and you will find my telephone number.  I dont give it out to just anyone but it sounds like you need to talk.

Posts.Content: dreamwriter wrote: My daughter was on CBS (Canadian Channel) on a show called The National.  It is a news documentary type show.  Anyhoo, there is a film out about LARPing which puts the activity into a bad light.  Now both my daughters larp (Live Action Role Playing).  It is a chance for them to go off into the woods, pretend that they are imaginary characters and of course follow the rules of the game.  This is a stress reliever for most of the participants who are about 18-35 yr range. So my daughter was downtown handing out leaflets on what larping really was and that it was fun and safe.  Two of her friends were interviewed with Shayna in the background.  My friend called me to tell me she had seen it.  She was no blurry blob.... clear as day.  So that is just something cool and off the cancer track. Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2009 07:47PM dreamwriter wrote: Hi Kystyna I was dx stage 4 almost from the get go.  And I have had a liver tumor for almost 4 yrs. And it is shrinking due to hormone therapy.  I also have bone and lung mets.  I make my 4 yr anniversary in dec.  You are not a statistic.  You are not even a prognosis (I was originally prognosed as 9-12 months).  Oops... you are a human being and react individually.  Have faith in your treatment, ask questions until you understand and be an advocate for yourself.  If you cannot speak up for yourself, bring someone who can and will. Example:  I am shy around nurses.  I see them as busy and they dont need to hear requests from me.  One day a nurse asked if I needed or would like anything and I said no... but my friend who was with me said.... wait... she has been complaining all day that she would like her hair washed.  15 minutes later I had clean hair.

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2011 07:22AM dreamwriter wrote: My suggestion is to talk to your doctor about some medicinal help to get through this difficult period.  Most of us have some form of anti-depressants in our daily pill cocktails.  There is no shame in asking for help.  As for getting through this, be thankful for each day you wake up.  Fill your days with fun and laughter... I took up quilting which is something I always wanted to do.  I also crochet and read a lot.  If you are not working, find ways to enjoy your "free" time.  Also, I agree with the rads suggestion.  I have had a lot of areas radiated for pain.... and it does work and it is a painless process.

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2010 10:17AM dreamwriter wrote: I have pleural effusions.  They told me because of my BC and lung involvement it was probably malignant.... didnt even test for it... just presumed.  However the Pleurothesis they tried to do did not work and I got a pneumothorax.  They drained some fluid out and tested it (different hospital) and that fluid was cancer free.  So do not let them jump to conclusions, tell them you want proof. I found that sleeping propped up helps... you can buy a wedge cushion for about $40CDN.  The more upright you are the better the air supply and the less groggy you are.  And that will help you enjoy your vacation. I hope your vacation is a wonderful week.

Posts.Content: May 3, 2011 05:45PM dreamwriter wrote: I was dx stage 4 one month after learning I had BC.  It was like getting slapped in the face twice.  I too changed hospitals.  I followed the money, a hospital with more money has more options IMHO.  And I had a doctor that did not communicate with me.  I have had a mastectomy, chemo, rads, hormonal drugs (or really anti-hormonal drugs as they were intended to strip all estrogen from my body).  Anyhoo, that was 5 and a half yrs ago.  So breathe, meditate, pray if you're into that, whatever gives you peace.  Like the others said, get your second opinion and make sure that you and your cancer team is a good "fit".  I wish you luck.  There are people here willing to hold you up psychologically.  You've made a few friends today that may be part of your support group 5 yrs or more from now.

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2010 07:37AM dreamwriter wrote: Hi I had the first year in chemotherapy but I had some organ activity.  I think that because yours is in the bone and you are highly estrogen driven, the tamoxifen can hold back the cancer more effectively than anything else.  I am on femara which is not too much different from tamoxifen.  I would expect that they will give you something for your bones... ie a biophosphate (mine is pamidronate). As for the freaking out.... how natural is that.... I do have a therapist and the hospital started me on anti depressants and anti anxiety medication but at very low doses.  The therapist helps me talk through... how long will I live, what will it be like when I die.... and even what happens after. And then there is here.  This has been a lifeline for the last year.  Strange that it was only a year ago and I have made so many friends (and I mean friends), had so much love and support, and been given the opportunity to support others (which makes me feel useful).  I have lost a few friends but their love, generosity of spirit and support were worth the pain.  I hope you find a home away that allows your stress to come out and your individuality to shine through this horror.

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2010 12:46PM dreamwriter wrote: I am basically house bound.... especially with winter weather.  But there is someone or something that happens each day to make it different from the others.  If I can get out I go to my quilting class and participate in girl guides as a leader.  Even chores can significantly change the day... participating in everyday life with the usual vitality.  I remember getting the girls off to school and the big silence as they scrambled down the hall.  Thats when your mind weighs you down.  It is that time you plan something, anything.... just to get through the next few minutes.  If you continue to feel down.... talk to your doc.... there are medications you can take temporarily (better living through chemistry).  I wish I was smart enough to get through chemistry LOL. This is not a short term ailment.  It is years of living with this thing wrong, that thing working, this scanxiety, that elation at hearing about stability, that despair with the diagnoses of progression.  Every day is a success whether you sit on your bum or clean the house like a hurricane.

I often laugh it all off as a three dimentional family tree - with some rather spoiled fruit and a few keepers. I do have a lot of friends collected from high school, college..... I seem to love teachers.... lol I take the loving of all of those that count and ignore the rest.  What a waste of time trying to get someone into your space.   Either they are there for you like the posters on the boards and in the chat rooms, or they're in another space - say hello and leave it alone.  I know it hurts but its better than hoping for what isnt gonna happen.

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2010 07:47PM dreamwriter wrote: Once you are Stage 4 you are always stage 4.  There is no preventing it from coming back... there is "no evidence of disease"  which means that they cant see it.  And there is "stable"  where they are controlling the disease.  Depending on where her mets are, there may be no ability to getting to NED and stable is the best you can get.  Even if you get to No Evidence of Disease (NED) and the cancer crops up it is not considered as returning, it is considered to have been there up to now just too small to show up on any test.

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2010 12:32PM dreamwriter wrote: I was diagnosed with bc Dec 2005 and by end of January 2006 we were aware of the bone mets.  My spine is peppered with them.  I went into chemo (FEC) for 6 sessions 3 weeks apart. That didnt work,  Then taxotere weekly for 18 sessions.  By the end of that I was a mess.  My fingernails were like talons, my hair was gone and my skin was gray.  I was mutuating into a bald eagle!  But the taxotere stablized the cancer.  Brought it to a screeching halt.  Within a month, the nails began to grow and my hair (cut to GI Jane look) started to come in fuzzy and soft.  And the pain levels were being well treated by pain meds.  Life seemed good, I was learning to quilt, traveling to meet ladies from the chat room - I was becoming a brand new person and I like her.  I told you all this to show that if something doesnt work - the next thing might.  Taxotere was my last chemo.  Now I am on Femara and that is keeping everything stable.

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2012 12:03AM - edited Feb 3, 2012 12:09AM by dreamwriter I found this site Feb 2008 and I dont remember how.  I was dx with BC Dec 20/05 and stage IV on January 25, 2006, after bone and cat scans after single mast.  I started with FEC, moved on to taxotere and that took me up to Feb 2007.  Lost hair twice.  Lost fingernails.  Then I was stable and was put on tamoxifen and femara when the taxoxifen failed.  Had pleural effusion - both lungs.  Then one had a collapsed area and I got another chest tube for that.  Was put on Faslodex and mystery drug but that gave me fluid around the heart.  They couldnt treat that so I went home.  I got blood clots in 2011 and now I have to have a shot of blood thinner every day.  They put me on oxygen which made me feel tied down to the apartment.  Now I am only on O2 at night so I do get to go out and socialize.  Now on Xeloda, am stable and its been 6 yrs since dx.  Which is good because original dx was for 9 to 12 months.  Imagine how freaked out we were! Edit:  I got to go to Los Vegas in 2008 and Florida in 2009 or 2010 and met some of the most wonderful women from the chat room in BCO.  It was the first time I travelled alone and meet people I only knew on the internet.  They were just as fabulous in person as they were in chat. Edit:  My name is Regina, dreamwriter is my girl guide moniker (been a leader for 15 yrs)

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2009 12:03AM dreamwriter wrote: As I said above, my first onco was horrible.  I failed to mention that his receptionist was/is the best.  She made sure I got all my forms for Social Security Disability and a huge tax break available to disabled people.  She sympathized with my situation. Once I was sobbing about a drug I could not afford and she was doing the "there there, I have called the social worker"  my onco walked around me 3 times to continue dealing with other patients.  Did I mention I was sobbing? This is the doctor who got me to stable so I do have to thank him for that.  However, he failed to give me any information because he was God.  I had no right to be questioning him. I changed hospitals, got into a clinical study, and my doctor is English, a real Dr. Bean (think sliding hospital furniture and sub-coordinated doctor).  The nurse I was given, spent 2 and a half hours explaining every scan, every question, every side effect.  She never once looked at her watch, made me feel there were other patients waiting.... she was the nicest thing to happen to me since the words, "You have breast cancer". So sometimes the receptionist may be your very best friend in a time of need.

Posts.Content: May 11, 2010 07:25PM dreamwriter wrote: Weeze.... I am a Torontonian too!  Contact CCAS  416 506-9888 and ask for an assessment for your mother.  Through here, you can access housekeeping, nursing.... etc etc and most importantly ask for an Ontario Drug Card which will save your mother a lot of money, even if she has private coverage through an insurer (ie Sun Life, London Life).  If something is not covered it can be through the private insurer.  If something is not covered ask why not - it may be something simple like 400mg gabapentin is not covered but 200 mg is.  So..... take 2 pills instead of 1.  Im just full of these ideas... if you wish to contact me .... look at the top where it says private messages  and read the one with my phone number... love Regina.

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2010 10:31AM dreamwriter wrote: Cheryl.... in the hospital they give me lactulose if the senekot is not working.  They do this in addition to the senekot.  This is like a laser blaster.... it moves everything you ever ate out.  The trick is then to start putting in so that it comes out properly.  The worst thing you can do is sit on the toilet for hours and strain.  However, I understand that when taking all this stuff, every fart is worthy of a hurried trip to the bathroom... how can you tell a fart cramp from a productive cramp?  You cant so every fart is dangerous.

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2009 11:47PM dreamwriter wrote: I bought the pill containers at the drug store that have pockets for each day of the week. Since one of my medications is 3 times daily, I have 3 of them. Yellow for morning, pink for afternoon and blue for night-time. I have had problems with drugs before and my hubby could show that I had taken the right amounts for the right time period.  He also knows all my drugs, what they are for and can advocate for me should there be any questions.  Doing it this way also means that I only carry the pink tray with me if I go out. And I dont have to remember to checkmark a chart. Hope this helps.

Posts.Content: May 13, 2009 11:03AM - edited May 13, 2009 11:04AM by dreamwriter To the ladies with men with buzzsaw snoring. Get him to a sleep test. They are the most amazing soft beds and the wires and stuff keep you firmly in place. You will have the most wonderful sleep that night. The next morning, you get dressed, they take the leads off and give you a diagnosis. In Ontario, usually a salesman will come to your door. The machine CPAP (Continual Pressured Air P....) the mind is going. It is a machine that costs some $1600 but the Assistive Devices pays the first 75 percent. And if you have insurance they will pay 80-100% of the remainder. Mine was $1600, ADP paid $1200. My insurance paid $320 so I was left with a bill of $80. I had to pay by cheque the $400 but they had us post date so we could get the insurance portion into the bank account. The reason Im saying this is as we get older we can develop sleep apnea, causing the snoring. And it is not just the sound but the bed can vibrate too. If your man has sleep apnea, the first night with the machine will give him an adrenalin rush the next morning. He will finally have enough oxygen during sleep. I have a CPAP machine so that is why I know all this. Sometimes weight loss or quitting smoking will make the machine unnecessary. But dont throw it out..... weight fluctuates, and quitting smoking is hard to do.
